037014E8249B4C8EB0CFE994AA13CB5B.description: Research and discuss the issue of storage of electrical energy as a barrier to large scale adoption of renewable energy resources.

20FB7D1A46F548F7BA9A91F6BA9871DE.description: Explain how electrical energy is produced in hydrogen fuel cells and various types (e.g., lead-acid, nickel-cadmium, alkaline and lithium-ion) of batteries.

D712442559FD4CB5B5505A3DE8070D8C.description: Research the role of oxidation and reduction in First Nations and Métis practices (e.g., drying and smoking meat for preservation)

1A5BD6282D5A44C480D33D83C159ACFA.description: Examine the role of oxidation and reduction in biological processes (e.g., photosynthesis, respiration and the action of antioxidants).

05A3E18C3C1147FCACE2AA5894CD333C.description: Investigate the process of corrosion and its prevention (e.g., painting and coating, cathodic protection, alloys, sacrificial anodes and avoiding incompatible metals)

3E81DB1049F74E638D41B34CFAE04B96.description: Design and carry out experiments which illustrate the processes of electrolysis and electroplating.

05B59EA46BC245ADBDE54DA576488897.description: Investigate the impact of the electrochemical industry on the environment, including disposal of raw materials, batteries and mine tailings

0E4720C839104033BB0E9F15F310B17E.description: Evaluate the economic importance of electrochemical technologies and processes.

67484D088EFA472F9D20E972101E7D4E.description: Provide examples of oxidation-reduction (redox) reactions that occur in nature and in technological processes.

6E9C436F201740E88623B8A32181D1A0.description: Design, construct, and evaluate a prototype of a working battery that meets specific student-identified criteria such as powering a small electric device.

F0FDB352C25D4B29B9F48EDC8DC7966B.description: Predict the electric potential and spontaneity of various redox reactions using reduction potentials.

11C25A6A25BF46B9BF0A35DA1979B6AF.description: Differentiate between electrochemical and electrolytic cells in terms of spontaneity, direction of electron flow, energy, charge on electrodes and chemical change.

ED57F2B7920D48448504C99E162EFB07.description: Illustrate and label the parts of electrochemical and electrolytic cells and explain how they work, including halfreactions, flow of ions and flow of electrons.

BC9A5602D57547A596A10F7D3D1D95D9.description: Create a reduction potential series based on studentcollected data.

8BE06BE485D84455800C95E14F817ECF.description: Write and balance redox equations using the half reaction and oxidation number method.

AF41111AA4CE4C05B4E7D556343599C9.description: Define oxidation and reduction and oxidizing and reducing agents in terms of electron transfer.

AE0E8D53F2AD48F286950C09F3403D54.description: Compare the characteristics of oxidation-reduction (redox) reactions with other types of chemical reactions.

BEAFA67968BB4A56BD8FC1017454D1BF.description: Investigate the chemistry of oxidation and reduction (redox) reactions.

C020BEF51AD849E18D3A457AA68F2956.description: Discuss the role of acid-base buffering as an aspect of maintaining homeostasis in biological systems.

61C308D3C4A34A38B4F336CEE5D247C3.description: Interpret pH titration curves for various combinations and strengths of acids and bases, by identifying endpoints and choosing appropriate indicators.

B19F4ABC82C44D82A7AEBA012228612E.description: Perform acid-base titrations and relevant calculations for multiple ratios of [H+ ]/[H3O+ ] to [OH- ], including those for reactions that either reach the endpoint/equivalence point or represent over-titration.

3FE1B0D817524D7A82E660CC194164CD.description: Design and carry out an experiment to differentiate between weak and strong acids using indicators.

D7CC94261349432D8783A5FFF63A24D1.description: Estimate the pH of solutions using acid-base indicator solutions and indicator papers.

DCD2A61CD1D34CEB904FDE19B2C52085.description: Explain how acid-base indicators function chemically, using Le Chatelier’s principle.

4173284D5C8E4698BEDFEA2C1DD346CF.description: Solve problems involving pH, pOH, [H+ ]/[H3O+ ], [OH- ], Kw, Ka and Kb.

BAB4918067604EECB3C6D0B312E88946.description: Discuss the relationship between [H+ ]/[H3O+ ] and [OH- ] in the dissociation of water, to explain Kw and perform relevant calculations.

4AD58E8401C848F3A85CBC0DE1CB4200.description: Classify strong and weak acids and bases using the magnitude of Ka and Kb.

1647424ADE8C4333AE093BCA90DD10AF.description: Differentiate between strength (strong versus weak) and concentration (concentrated versus dilute) when referring to acids and bases.

303A6F6D9C134A8CBD15768233395404.description: Identify conjugate acids and bases formed in acid-base reactions using Brønsted-Lowry theory, including substances which are amphiprotic (amphoteric).

FEDF96F308394410AC0D91FED17724B2.description: Discuss the historical development and limitations of theories, including Arrhenius, Brønsted-Lowry and Lewis, which explain the behaviour of acids and bases.

5FBDE91E375847218F51144051D61171.description: Identify examples of acid-base reactions in the manufacture and use of consumer products (e.g., foods, cosmetics, pharmaceuticals and cleaners), industrial processes (e.g., resource extraction and refining, mine tailings), agricultural processes (e.g., fertilizer and pesticide application) and First Nations and Métis practices such as tanning hides.

4B7DF6D65B7740FC9F4D2224EF36840B.description: Observe and analyze phenomena related to acidbase reactions and equilibrium.

AA5F89A3999D424EB7ACB5DEF1ADB904.description: Predict whether a precipitate will occur in a double replacement reaction when given the initial concentration of reactants and solubility product constant (Ksp) values of the products.

9EE1DBCB62A14781813F814F83711FC7.description: Calculate the solubility of substances in aqueous solutions, given Ksp

A8D19D008D694E93AC551D1782BF6667.description: Calculate the solubility product constant (Ksp) for saturated solutions, given solute concentrations

DD52BE05AA904F9299EB2523DF41CB93.description: Interpret solubility curves of selected substances

BF80E353616642C7955174F1B1AB2585.description: Construct solubility graphs from student collected data to demonstrate the effect of temperature on the change in solubility of chemical compounds in water.

C47D9D02ADE54D28955903E601E6E598.description: Research applications of solution equilibria in Saskatchewan agriculture, resource extraction, manufacturing and chemical industries.

05AC03854EF64682AAA650603EBFF614.description: Predict the changes in solution equilibrium caused by changes in temperature, pressure, volume, concentration or the addition of a catalyst, using Le Chatelier’s principle.

04CAB40E246541208EAD8526EA919D7F.description: Analyze how temperature and the common ion effect influence the solubility of substances in aqueous solution.

96355D5906314374A7CE6B6A2C9E73FA.description: Discuss conditions necessary for the establishment of equilibrium in aqueous solutions.

3A55FD065D514F559BC4B97994C8D085.description: Analyze aqueous solution equilibria including solubility-product constants.

B55FBE61E5044511A6869A8B39534F63.description: Examine how the concepts of reversible reactions and equilibrium apply to biological systems.

D8F30DD2CB8649B887DD03BB32B0386D.description: Describe ways in which industry manipulates chemical reactions to change the equilibrium point to make processes economically viable.

490EE52C68464E66AED0E7A6B61073CC.description: Describe the Haber process, its historical significance and societal impacts.

7E71515EAA1945BA8DA5A2E6A6D23865.description: Construct a model or design an experiment that demonstrates the concepts of equilibrium and/or Le Chatelier’s principle.

6CD12D242D9D46D0A3A0C1C0D281AE35.description: Predict the shifts in equilibrium caused by changes in temperature, pressure, volume, concentration or the addition of a catalyst, using Le Chatelier’s principle.

2BAA988E1A774997A9EC84483B3FDCB3.description: Solve problems related to chemical equilibrium, using Initial concentration, Change in concentration and Equilibrium concentration (ICE) charts.

0007F7A45C8C4D1CBBB38F834D40ECF7.description: Perform calculations involving Keq and the equilibrium concentrations of reactants and products.

2C1E20653495410D821A7A19AAD5677E.description: Interpret Keq values to determine whether the concentration of products, reactants or neither is favoured once equilibrium has been reached.

304AE23F704B426BBC7D37516120CEEB.description: Explain why solid and liquid phases have no effect on the value of an equilibrium constant.

732083B407E045E2BB1154CF96DECDA1.description: Recognize that equilibrium constant (Keq) values are dependent upon pressure (for gases only) and temperature but are independent of concentration and the presence of a catalyst.

64BBD4E43B6849E2826336368A8D20B3.description: Write the equilibrium constant (Keq) expression for a variety of chemical reactions.

72925DBFB0C14E07A4975731B3C68B9B.description: Analyze graphs of the concentrations of reactants and products with respect to time in chemical reactions which approach equilibrium, chemical reactions which achieve equilibrium and chemical reactions which undergo a change in equilibrium.

F9CC118816164C3699B5BD1773473CB0.description: Discuss the criteria (e.g., closed system, constancy of properties and equal rates of forward and reverse reactions) that characterize an equilibrium system.

796AB061A9C04EF6AB9AFCDA83889955.description: Discuss why most chemical reactions do not proceed to completion.

609B5F0E38B64EC28B06A1E9442D5B88.description: Consider, qualitatively and quantitatively, the characteristics and applications of equilibrium systems in chemical reactions.

468B813F0B1B40BBABBE9F96CDFFD879.description: Analyze how a product (e.g., sporting equipment, vehicle, clothing or building material) has evolved in response to the development of new materials.

191E87564D934016A1F7862FBF4A6E63.description: Investigate the potential of modern materials (e.g., graphene, aerogels, polymers and carbon nanotubes) to change the way we live.

E8D8B24B09D2414BABC96D2FF5F8E9C6.description: Justify the use of the material chosen for a specific application based on student-selected criteria.

D9A98C6A72444ED7B9EEDFA1B0AE2BAC.description: Identify criteria (e.g., cost, availability, ethics, transportation cost and source of material) used to guide the choice of materials for a specific application.

27E0555546BC4C0D874F8AB59D4B9E24.description: Research First Nations and Métis beliefs regarding the ethical treatment of Mother Earth with respect to the gathering, creating, using and disposing of materials.

956BED77FD8B4CBDACFF3885EECF67E0.description: Explore how First Nations and Métis people used their understanding of material properties to determine their use (e.g., different species of wood used for burning, smoking and creating structures for housing and transportation).

E99FBB4C1DDF40328F607EAFD8DC7893.description: Suggest a range of suitable applications for a material based on its chemical and physical properties.

028296BB38DB4417BF2F46E94CA98D3F.description: Evaluate the risks and benefits to society and the environment of a product (real or imagined) throughout its life cycle, from raw materials to production, use and disposal.

BD4CA90DB0084542853607145770B3F3.description: Determine the properties of a material that make it suitable to meet the specifications for a particular product (e.g., catalysts and solvents for oil extraction and refining, metals in equipment for mining, bulletproof fabric, nanotechnologies, superconductors and instant adhesives).

A62E9773C0D1422983AE21EF06ECE9C6.description: Determine the suitability of materials for use in specific applications.

5D42145B708642A288CDF46942A05373.description: Design and carry out a procedure to synthesize an organic compound (e.g., soap, esters and polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) polymer slime).

1F4A3E6764D94462BA3C540B2B3F0DCC.description: Describe processes of polymerization and explain the significance of some natural and synthetic polymers

1C85D99FD293467CAF4B4468AFFD1425.description: Research some societal benefits and environmental impacts related to the petrochemical industry.

382D3B7F98BF4FDE92564D43EDD44476.description: Provide examples of consumer and industrial products that are derived from the refining of fossil fuels.

7195B941410E403D9D05B21874C87DFD.description: Research how First Nations and Métis people used organic compounds as medicines and to make soap and cleaning products.

9A7B8F4E1CB2447496CC53A9A0572476.description: Describe applications of the various classes of organic compounds, including compounds (e.g., carbohydrates, lipids, proteins, nucleic acids) important to biological systems.

85EB58755FE645F7BA1D014C485FC7EF.description: Identify various classes of organic compounds based on functional groups including cyclics, aromatics, alcohols, aldehydes, ketones, ethers, esters, organic acids and halocarbons.

BEE4027FC0584F91997E3871F0120EE1.description: Discuss the importance of isomerization, including geometric and optical isomerization, in materials science and biological applications.

D27C24ACD1194188907D94F8CEE1F54D.description: Provide the IUPAC names, and illustrate, using diagrams, molecular modelling kits and/or digital technology, the structural formulas of a variety of branched- and straight-chain hydrocarbons.

778FE05D2F6840BAACF4DB227E58FE6D.description: Write the molecular and structural formula and provide the International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry (IUPAC) name for a representative sample of straight-chain alkanes, alkenes and alkynes, with up to 10 carbon atoms in the molecule.

7615E9AC605841CA853AC910C4A3D7F1.description: Describe and compare the advantages of using different models (e.g., molecular, structural, condensed-structural, space-filled, 2-dimensional and 3-dimensional) to represent organic molecules.

306D7A10888848F9BD4E0EE65176E5A0.description: Explain how the valence structure of carbon leads to the large number and diversity of organic compounds in nature

620AFEA5A11A46F5A7BA623DB6F50315.description: Pose questions about the prevalence and diversity of organic compounds in daily life.

721D6E06C64B4C80B30D81C4CBD3D116.description: Explore the nature and classification of organic compounds, and their uses in modern materials.

2A27DB58466143A4B0D7C7ACFD772058.description: Recognize the limitations of personal and scientific classification schemes.

F21B799807824C57A6C1067D7402EE51.description: Place new substances into a student-constructed classification system based on their properties.

74FBB7B7ADDC4B108DF5DDBE6CA9D1DC.description: Determine which intermolecular force is dominant in a studenttested material, based on test results and knowledge of intermolecular forces.

92B9D16D41E44F9087A1CE1D8516B46D.description: Construct a classification system of student-tested materials according to one or more properties.

C438686AC53641079153378B148A5AF7.description: Design and carry out a procedure to compare several physical and chemical properties of various materials (e.g., sugar, salt, sand, paradichlorobenzene [mothballs], paraffin and beeswax).

B9D166E3D97D4A28AFECF94408909A52.description: Identify and describe some properties (e.g., melting point, solubility, thermal conductivity, electrical conductivity, hardness, heat capacity, tensile strength, surface tension, reactivity with acids and bases, flammability, flame tests and odour) of ionic and molecular compounds, metals and network covalent substances.

F4D78CA0461B4BFC8C4F726D04DEF276.description: Recognize that a material’s chemical and physical properties are dependent on the type of bonds and the forces between atoms, molecules or ions.

4916E9D02654441A8DAA278838D54A1B.description: Differentiate between the different types of intermolecular (i.e., van der Waals [i.e., London dispersion, dipole-dipole, hydrogen bonding and ion-dipole], ionic crystal and networkcovalent) and intramolecular (i.e., non-polar covalent, polarcovalent, ionic and metallic) forces.

F3E87653869B440BB5ED0DBF09770D4B.description: Predict the polarity of molecules using the property of electronegativity and VSEPR theory.

9D5DE56846AF4E2791CBFBDEDC4B61DC.description: Investigate how the properties of materials are dependent on their underlying intermolecular and intramolecular forces.

569E06A0A2B544B98639C912613ADE29.description: Predict the nature of chemical bonds within a molecule using the property of electronegativity.

23C85F116BBF424CB49A90EDC3072756.description: Predict the geometry and draw the shapes of molecules with a single central atom using valence shell electron pair repulsion (VSEPR) theory.

0A48A0DA93294DFCBFFE3A5AD7A6C0B1.description: Predict the arrangement of atoms and draw Lewis structures (electron dot structures) to represent covalent- and ionicbonded molecules.

02CBD3C4F6AA452D994F9FD8DA0A98C3.description: Discuss the role of valence electrons in the formation of covalent and ionic bonds, including the connection to metals and non-metals.

E2ED8F7BB1954290A522AB82D7F07390.description: Draw Lewis structures (electron dot structures) for group 1 and 2 elements and non-metals, and their ions, based on an understanding of valence electrons.

15B6AF3B6A644122B988DA374992D11F.description: Explain the formation of ions and predict their charge in group 1 and 2 elements and non-metals, based on an understanding of valence electrons and the octet rule.

DBA8BF0104134761BCB7D50DE8C77C77.description: Explain the relationship between the position of an element on the periodic table and its number of valence electrons with reference to the octet rule.

B45D552935A64F50844D136687A4DA45.description: Examine how evidence and experimentation inform the development and refinement of theories in chemistry.

F306922BFB354E9DB75417EB0BAB28C9.description: Discuss the value of representing scientific understanding of the atom using various types of models, including molecular formula, structural formula, space-filling molecular model, balland-stick molecular model and Lewis structure.

568BADED5ECA45FEA10EDF0AE3AD1A4A.description: Trace the historical development of the model of the atom from Bohr to the modern quantum understanding, including the contributions of Einstein, Planck, Heisenberg and DeBroglie.

19D47F139F2C4B938C051C3D7D403834.description: Examine the role of valence electrons in the formation of chemical bonds

3D043A6747144E6CBC5AC08C33E63E02.description: Construct a tool (e.g., rubric, checklist, self-evaluation form or peer-evaluation form) to assess the process and products involved in a student-directed study.

93215C5D544F448A8629CE23309FD6E7.description: Share the results of student-directed research through a display, presentation, performance, demonstration, song, game, commercial, fine art representation, video or research paper.

80CFB86FEFFC4A8DA7D43A44B8F0A0E4.description: Debate an issued related to chemistry, including developing materials to support the arguments for and arguments against a position.

3E74408E896B4245BBD273C868CF5644.description: Design, construct and evaluate the effectiveness of a device, model or technique that demonstrates the scientific principles underlying concept related to a Chemistry 30 topic.

3DAD808C36EE4F2D8293B7F0896ACD1D.description: Assemble and reflect on a portfolio that demonstrates an understanding of a topic of interest related to chemistry.

8A38BE7A29084838B994DF0B5AF876DA.description: Carry out an experiment following established scientific protocols to investigate a question of interest related to one or more of the topics of Chemistry 30

841132FBBAF840B2BDA120BB14D6A4E6.description: Design a scientific investigation related to a topic of study in Chemistry 30 that includes a testable question, a hypothesis, an experimental design that will test the hypothesis and detailed procedures for collecting and analyzing data.

583004CABFF842D68982A7BA0B6AE0FB.description: Create and carry out a plan to explore one or more topics of personal interest relevant to Chemistry 30 in depth.
